@undertheteacup Modeling it after Adventurer and Troll, there could be two triggers for the final scene:
1) If Tension hits 6, or
2) If the partiers invite the Detective to stay.
Then some sort of mechanic to determine what kind of ending?

@undertheteacup So, maybe Tension die goes up whenever something raises the detective's suspicion? And anytime something happens that draws the detective into those simple pleasures of mundane life, the genre shifts towards slice of life?
@undertheteacup For reference: https://t.co/GkAWPjzYEI

@undertheteacup https://t.co/GkAWPjzYEI
I'm modeling it on the core mechanic from Adventurer and Troll (which you can see in the sample image on the site).

@undertheteacup Okay, okay. How about this. Two core mechanics. The tone/genre of the gathering slides from Murder Mystery to Slice Of Life (open to refining both terms). Then there is something that exerts pressure on the story/game... something that influences the pacing (cont)
@undertheteacup YES! I love that!

@undertheteacup There's a mechanic that tracks "patience" (which influences pacing of the game) and "trust" (which influences the final outcome).

What if there is a "pressure/patience/threat" track (paces the game) and "mysterious/mundane" track (shapes tone and the ending)?

@undertheteacup Okay. So I have an idea for this one. There's a 2 player game called Adventurer and Troll (I think that's the name), where the Adventurer is trying to cross the bridge the Troll guards...

Villain/Victim. If Villain reaches 6, you do a murder. If Victim reaches 6, you are murdered.

Shady/Sleuth. If Shady reaches 6, you turn to a life of crime. If Sleuth reaches 6, you become a detective and are doomed to solve crimes everywhere you go.
@undertheteacup Ooo... Interesting! So you could pull the detective out of the genre! Save them from a life of case after case--even when on vacation. I like that.

Maybe instead both stats are related to archetypes in the mystery genre. That would be more like traditional Honey Heist. Your goal would be to get Detective to leave before either one hits an end point... I like that line of thought. Let's follow it for a minute

If anyone in your group hits 6 Mysterious, they slip away and do a murder, the detective gets a case, and you're all stuck in a mystery plot. If anyone in your group hits 6 Mundane... hmm... Does that mean that the detective gets bored and leaves? I don't know about that...

Okay, I'm thinking a Honey Heist hack. Maybe you have two stats, Mysterious and Mundane. Your goal is to get the Detective to leave your gathering. As you become more Mysterious, you become more like a mystery novel character. As you become more mundane, u... become more mundane. https://t.co/70MLPvhSoa

This game idea is inspired by my realization that I don't want to be in a detective story. And if I realized I was in one, I would try my damndest to get the detective to take a different train, get off the boat, leave the party, stay at a different hotel, etc.

Maybe there is a mechanic where the lo get the detective stays, the more your characters become archetypes and tropes from the mystery genre?

So you need them to leave before things spiral out of control. But you are a member of polite society and can't just kick them out.

Okay, whar about a microrpg where you play genre savvy characters trying to get the world famous detective to leave before someone dies? Because you know that whenever he sticks around somewhere long enough, the detective always catches a body.

@TheGiftOfGabes Thanks! He's okay. He's just got the doggie equivalent of vertigo. Usually gets better over the first few days, and goes away in no longer than a few weeks. But his balance is all off for now, so he needs help getting around.

Also, Dragon Dice fucking slapped. That game is the only collectible game I've ever had any serious interest in. And I really want to track down my old dice at my parents' place and take them to my FLGS!

Also, in case anyone is worried. My dogs are both okay. George just developed "old dog vestibular syndrome." Which means his balance is really off and his eyes are kinda twitchy. Happens with old dogs sometimes and usually goes away on its own after a few days. He's resting now.

Yes, my body is worse at staying up all night. But also, I apparently stay up all night for much less enjoyable things.

I need to find my old dragon dice and show you why the swamp stalkers are where it's at.

Pulling an all nighter has become less fun as I get older.
Age 9, first time: played Dragon Dice until dad woke up at 5am and told us to go to bed.
High School: Mostly video games or homework
College: Dates, Friends or homework
Grad School: Papers
Age 35: Emergency vet visit

Biggest of all? I'm just sitting on the floor with him. He is my favorite person and best friend, so this one is easy. But it is also really crucial. Since losing his vision, he really only seems distressed when he can't find Z and I. So, I am staying close by to help him rest.💜

We brought his food to him for breakfast this morning. (Breakfast in bed like the Princess that George has always been.) And I have been offering his water bowl occasionally so he doesn't *have* to get up. Gonna find a way to raise it too for easier access.

To help limit falling, we are trying to keep the floor in our room as clutter free as possible AND shifted some area rugs and runners to minimize the amount of slippery (faux) hard wood he has to navigate.

We are limiting his movements mostly to our bedroom, but I am trying to let him practice walking as he wants. I read that (as long as he doesn't get hurt) standing and walking can allow their proprioception (sense of body in space) to help their balance.

There isn't much you can do to remove symptoms during an episode. But there are things you can do to provide support. I just learned and wanted to share. We use a loosely rolled towel slipped under his belly/hips as a makeshift harness to support his back legs.

So yeah, for a couple days our mostly blind and deaf dog is gonna struggle with balance. But it apparently usually just goes away after a bit, and is almost always worst just during the first 24-72 hours.

He finally seems to have found a comfy position to sleep: 3/4 off his bed. https://t.co/GCD0PUBZDx

So, apparently older dogs sometimes get idiopathic vestibular disease. Idiopathic: they don't know the cause. Vestibular: the system that controls balance. So they just lose their sense of balance (and have weird eye movements) for a few days-weeks.

This was fun. It also gives me good north stars to keep in sight while I'm designing and refining games.

The secret heart of [Redacted]--the game I'm putting the most focus on right now--is community organizing/activism within a hostile and oppressive society. It's about working to better and protect a city that will, in all likelihood, never understand or care for you.

The secret heart of Skate For Your Life (which is currently unpublished again, but which I want to get back to in the next week) is gentrification. And how it interweaves with daily life. Also smooches.

The secret heart of Ubuntu System Failure is two things in tension: 1) we become who we are through our relationships, and 2) our longest and most important relationships can become defined by the things we fail to talk about or address.

The secret heart of How Do You Do Fellow Humans is the alienation and isolation that comes from living in a society that teaches you it's unsafe to be open about your queerness--unsafe to be openly "different". How it can stop us from finding each other.
False Protagonists is easy for me to identify. The secret heart of FP is growing up queer,  becoming disillusioned with your queer heroes/idols, and deciding who you want to be in the world.

Note: here I'm using "secret heart" to refer to what the game means *to me specifically.* I'm still a baby designer, and a lot of what I've created is very minimal and unpolished. So I don't pretend to claim this core comes through to others. But I like thinking about it.

I recently came across the idea of "the secret heart" of a game that I keep thinking about. (Shout out to @/KevinPetker for coining the term and @/bleongambetta for the thread where I found it.) So I figured I'd try to ID the secret heart of a few of my games. #designthoughts 🧵

Funny story. I don't have any blank white paper, because we just moved and don't have most of our stuff. So it looks like I will NOT be doing the hand-written zine version of "Sing, Sweet Goddex" today. 🤣

I may create that version at a later time.🤷🏽‍♀️

Also, while it wasn't conscious, I am 100% sure I was partially inspired by the brilliant and hilarious "HWAET! There Is a Friend-Shaped Hole at the Center of Everything!" by @unplaytested and @TheAshCheshire about translating ancient epic poetry written by dire capybara.

It's inspired by "Typewriter Series #1102" by Tyler Knott Gregson:

Don't ever let them tell you
that waking up,
and reintroducing your feet
to the cold floor
below your
bed
isn't something
to be proud of.
Don't ever let them say
it's not brave
shutting your eyes
each night.

@UmActuallyShow @Marvel @enthusiamy @markeiamccarty @SamMaggs With exposure to radiation, typically as soon as you're out of it you are no longer being exposed to new danger. Contamination is the radioactive particles that get on you, on your stuff, or even in your body (like Iodine-131), and thus continues to expose you to radiation.

@UmActuallyShow @Marvel @enthusiamy @markeiamccarty @SamMaggs Loved the episode, and... Um, actually Potassium Iodide should be used in case of exposure to *radioactive contamination* (specifically Iodine-131). Used to work in a reactor and the distinction between radiation and contamination is super important to radiation health physics.

@FallOnMyBlade I mean. I guess you don't have to. You can choose to blow through them and ride the luck of the draw for the rest of the session. Which also sounds awesome.
@FallOnMyBlade And I love the sense of deep scarcity created by having to manage nonreplenishable resources over an entire session.

@FallOnMyBlade Oof. That sounds rad! I find diegetic resource management to be pretty boring in most games. (I don't want to count gold.) But I am a sucker for games where you manage more metanarrative resources like that. (FATE, No Dice No Masters, etc.)
@FallOnMyBlade But you ALWAYS have the option to try to just get out of the way. You just aren't as good at it if the other person knows you're out of ammo.
@FallOnMyBlade Ooo! I love that! Maybe one dice is always and only available for dodging too. So you have to split your time/focus between continuing to dodge and trying trying reload.

@FallOnMyBlade This has the benefit of feeling less hectic than the standoff dice mechanic, which might be too fast-paced for some players. This is much more deliberative--better suited for a mystery or a relational drama story.

@FallOnMyBlade Can play a card at any point to exert influence over the scene. There's no turns, and the tension comes from wondering what others are holding and when they will play it. The strategy comes from choosing when to play it.

@FallOnMyBlade Okay. What about this for a more narrative but still mechanically driven system? Players draw 4 cards at the beginning of a scene. There is an oracle that gives a meaning to each card. For example, maybe a jack means a character dies. The players roleplay the scene but
@FallOnMyBlade A fringe benefit is that it could lead to a real feeling of a standoff. Two players staring at each other throwing shade in character as they dare each other to take a shot.

@FallOnMyBlade That would allow there to be strategy in choosing how fast to play. Do you want to roll quickly and try to take someone out before you get got? Or do you wait and use your dice strategically once some of the showdown has already happened.

@FallOnMyBlade I could imagine something for an old west style shoot out where you've got six shots (let's say dice--although cards or something could work). When the shootout starts, you can start rolling and assigning hits. Once you are out of dice/bullets, you can't shoot any more.

Inspired by my favorite trope of creatures/robots learning to be human--particularly thinking about D20's Starstruck and Data from Star Trek. But also inspired by recent convos about walking meditations and mindfulness practice with my partner.

A solo larp where you have a newly acquired human body and you take time each day choosing a sense to explore. E.g., really focusing in on all the things you see up close and far away--colors, shapes, textures, objects--noting the emotions the sights elicit.

Next time I teach a course (especially if it's on games), I'll be experimenting with incorporating some ttrpg safety tools into it.

What might it look like for a group to co-create community agreements/gaming norms in a semi-structured way during session zero? How might it empower students to incorporate elements of script change into a classroom context?

These aren't hard and fast facts. But they are frequently the case. I can think of potential reasons for this difference in approach, but I also think each field/scene could probably learn more from the other and incorporate elements of its approach.

Been thinking about how safety tools in TTRPGs are often focused on "the what" (e.g. veils, lines, x cards) and how community agreements/conversation norms/ground rules in educational spaces are often focused on "the how" (e.g., share the mic, i-statements, etc.).

@DragonCobolt @jdragsky Maybe this is more colored by me cynically looking back at it, but so much of the lore and the mechanics of UA2 were around violent conflicts between groups. I think it feels like it's both trying to lean into the reality of violence and tell pulp/noir stories that center it.

@DragonCobolt @jdragsky But with the entire chapter on combat mechanics and the mechanical critical hit system (cherries, I believe they were called), it really feels like the game is encouraging you to find reasons to build characters that fight well and then fight with them. ::shrug:: ymmv

@DragonCobolt @jdragsky I'm not sure we were playing the game right either. This was back in UA 2e and I was a lot younger then. I mostly remember the trauma/madness mechanics functioning as a sort of... resistance mechanic combined with a character condition mechanic? Esp with psych first aid...

@DragonCobolt @jdragsky It may speak more to the way folks I played with ran the game, but it never felt like violence was super real and should be avoided. It felt more like violence was hashtag gritty and lethal, so it would feel that much "cooler" when we won a fight.

@DragonCobolt @jdragsky Despite it saying that, in my experience, it doesn't feel this way. I don't think I've played a single UA game where folks didn't end up doing massive amounts of violence, with relatively little in the way of actual weighty consequences.

Is there any media that combines magical girl tropes with monster hero tropes? I want a show with full-on magical transformation sequences where teens change into just big ol werewolves, hulking demons, and other monstrosities.

There are a pile of community copies, because capitalism is a hellscape and I make games for folks at the margins--folks who are less likely to have disposable income. If you end up giving this game a try, please tell me what you think! I'd love to chat about it! (5/5)

It's a game where you get to create your own queer heroes--where you decide what is heroic, what is forgivable, and what you value.

Or at least I hope it is! Because it's also still very much in playtesting! 😅
Check it out at https://t.co/RRJMKSKkiH! (4/5)

About the complicated feelings of being a queer teen who is trying to figure yourself out when so much of the world is telling you who and what you should be--about deciding which aspects of your role models you want to emulate and which you want to distance yourself from. (3/5)

This is definitely the most personal game I've released so far. It's about the process of growing up and realizing your heroes maybe aren't as heroic as you thought. It's about the fact that everyone causes harm--you, me, our loved ones, and, yes, even our heroes. (2/5)

@velaskgoodbye Thanks for asking. My understanding is that is what the whole game is about--navigating your family's rigid ideas about gender as someone who doesn't fit the boxes the way your family wants.

@DrawYourDicePod Anyway, big thanks to Nevyn Holmes and Jeremy Gage for getting my wheels spinning. I highly encourage y'all to go check out @DrawYourDicePod if you're not already a listener.

@DrawYourDicePod Immersion can be connected to flow states, or emotional investment, or meaningful engagement where players are fully in the present moment. (There's probably something interesting to say about mindfulness too, which I'm gonna think about later.)

@DrawYourDicePod I'm not convinced that immersion has to be about consistent, simulationist mechanics... or really anything diegetic, for that matter. It absolutely can be! But immersion is about getting lost in the moment or about your brain staying with the game even when you do other things.

@DrawYourDicePod Still listening to this podcast, and I'm now curious why "immersion" and "simulation" are used so synonymously (or nearly synonymously) in #TTRPG discourse. My most immersive experiences in playing video games have mostly been about the mechanics sucking me in... not the story.

@SirenaBesos @temporalhiccup Why hadn't I thought of how GREAT this game could be to play with kids!? It seems obvious now! Wow! I love this! I'm going to recommend it to all my friends with kids! Thank you for sharing this! :D

@OSRCARL Games like Star Crossed or Fiasco have really cleverly designed narrative systems that help shape the flow of the story--ratcheting up tension to create a particular play experience. All of these games are effective at what they do, but would fail if ported into D&D.

@OSRCARL But I'd argue that there are games that are entirely built around social and narrative mechanics. Prompt-based systems (like MF0: Firebrands) can provide inspiration/useful limits to help players role-play social scenes. For The Queen's prompts support narrative storytelling.

@OSRCARL I think you are making two different claims here--one of which I agree with wholeheartedly. D&D is not designed to support interesting social mechanics, and thus they usually fall flat. Same with games that are similar to D&D. So let's not try to add them to D&D.

@alien_barking @JacobSKellogg I say it's a blurry edge because it is debatable whether the character sheet impacts the fiction or just keeps track of the fiction.

I'm probably splitting hairs in this example. But it is interesting to me that the game rules can be about the characters or players.

@alien_barking @JacobSKellogg But the game could say explicitly that the player is required to update their character sheet, so that there won't be confusion later. Once it tells you that you have to do it, it's a rule. And in this case, it is a rule telling you to change something in the real world.

@alien_barking @JacobSKellogg Totally! So, let's say you level up in the game. The rules probably tell you all the ways your character is now more powerful. The rules *mighr* also tell you to change things on your character sheet (for instance to write your new hp. They might not. Some games assume you will.

It's just so good! (6/6)

4) It gives designers (including GMs who adjust or add questions) a highly flexible tool to focus the spotlight on (or nudge the story towards) certain aspects of the story. You could attach questions to moves, characters, settings, scenes, macguffins, whatever! (5/6)

3) Still facilitates character differentiation in two ways. Archetypes (represented by the playbooks) have unique q's that tell us something about the ways they take control in the story. And they are more/less likely to have the fictional positioning to say yes to move q's.(4/6)

2) Prioritizes fictional positioning. Related to the first point, +questions is about what is going on in the story rather than what "innate" qualities a given character has. This has (beneficial in my view) impacts on both the types of stories told and the way players play.(3/6)

1) It's dynamic. Stat bonuses for characters tend to be relatively stable--at least across a given session, if not an entire campaign. Question bonuses could vary pretty drastically even within a given scene. (2/6)

I've been thinking a lot about different approaches to the bonuses added to rolls in PbtA games, and I think I'm figuring out some of the reasons I love the "roll +questions" mechanic used by (and I believe created by) Brandon Leon-Gambetta for Pasion de las Pasiones. (1/6)

@blavnan I hadn't even thought of getting into the level of detail of directions or distance. I was thinking in more abstract terms. Hmmm... thanks. You've given me a bunch to ponder!

@blavnan My brother and I talked about it. The constraint of the jam is that it has to be able to be airbrushed on the side of a van. So unless the pieces are magnetic or adhesive, a battle map would be hard. lol

@blavnan Oh, conflict would have to be resolved hella fast. This absolutely can't be a strategically deep game. Pausing might even need to be penalized. Would it be too much chaos to have everyone resolving conflict at once?

@blavnan But also, are the classes really THAT different in the original gauntlet? They have diff stats... but maybe only 4 stats? Move speed, hp/defense, DPS (I can't remember if they have just diff damage or also attack speed, but functionally it's diff DPS), and magic.

@blavnan That's a question my bro and I will need to grapple with. Is it full on Gauntlet--so you can choose from different classes? Or is it Gauntlet inspired--in which case maybe you are the eponymous Blue Valkyrie and it's a solo game or a game with one pc and one GM?
@blavnan But you start with a TON of dice?
@blavnan Yeah! I was wondering if it is something where dice are slowly removed from your pool? So the dice function as both your hp and your attack?

@blavnan I'm actually toying with the idea of a game where you know you will die by the end. Like the name could be very literal--maybe even the first few words of the rules. B/C Gauntlet is unforgiving and basically unbeatable (for your average person at least).
@blavnan There needs to be some sort of countdown mechanic with a way to replenish it. It needs to feel like there are endless hordes of enemies.
@blavnan Yeah. I've been mulling that over. I think it's doable. Doing it in a single page (or several vertical "pages") so it could fit on one side of a van? That's the tricky part.

So, my current plan is to work with my brother (maybe both of them) to turn the og Gauntlet into a TTRPG for the #VanDoorJam. Working title?
Blue Valkyrie Is About To Die!

So, #ttrpg fam, doess that sound like a thing you'd want to play? Or at least read if you saw it on a van? https://t.co/WomeIXuFXh
